comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
I checked in the Thom's Directories and the Rabaiotti Bros. don't appear until 1910 at no. 49 Amiens Street (for a couple of years before that, an Angelo Santi worked out of that address).

The Rabaiotti's are listed as Merchants in 1910 and 1911. By 1914, they've expanded into no. 50 next door and are listed as Confectioners also.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: www.census.nationalarchives.ie/reels/nai000193785/ rabaiotti family in 1911 but very much Fish Merchants.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: There were Rabaiottis in Swansea when I lived there in the 1980s. I think they ran a café. Flickr confirms they are still there. Most of the well-known Italian cafe dynasties in South Wales came from the Bardi region in the 1920s/1930s. I wonder if the Irish Rabiottis are from the same part of Italy?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Streetview, OS 25" map link.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Describing the Italian cafe influx into South Wales www.walesonline.co.uk/news/local-news/proud-history-valle... This sentence struck me. "Various members of the Rabaiotti families also had cafes and ice-cream carts on the streets well before 1907." Perhaps the Irish ones came via S Wales.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Swan necked electric light visible...introduced 1903-1010 sometime.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Mabbot street entrance of nighttown, before which stretches an uncobbled tramsiding set with skeleton tracks, red and green will-o'-the-wisps and danger signals. Rows of grimy houses with gaping doors. Rare lamps with faint rainbow fins. Round Rabaiotti's halted ice gondola stunted men and women squabble. They grab wafers between which are wedged lumps of coral and copper snow. Sucking, they scatter slowly. Children. The swancomb of the gondola, highreared, forges on through the murk, white and blue under a lighthouse. Whistles call and answer.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Rabaiotti's in 1901.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: A onelegged sailor crutched himself round MacConnell's corner, skirting Rabaiotti's icecream car, and jerked himself up Eccles street. Towards Larry O'Rourke, in shirtsleeves in his doorway, he growled unamiably: —For England... He swung himself violently forward past Katey and Boody Dedalus, halted and growled: —home and beauty.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: And finally, Antonio Pabaiotti, the well-known ice-cream seller and misprint: At Antonio Pabaiotti's door Bloom halts, sweated under the bright arclamp. He disappears. In a moment he reappears and hurries on.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Evidently Rabaiotti's were selling ice-cream from their car by June the 16th 1904.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
There were Italian ice cream shops in coal mining towns all over North East England when I was young.
Some names I remember are Risi, Rea, Mark Toney, Minchella, Moscardini, Forte, Fella.
There could be a book in this.....

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Did another quick check... This is the alphabetical listing from the 1914 Thom's: Rabaiotti, Antoni, 65 Talbot street Rabaiotti Bros. fried fish saloon, 22 High st., 49 Amiens street Rabioath(typo for Rabaiotti?), H.A. ice cream vendor, 10 Capel street Rabiotti Bros. fried fish shop, 156 Parnell street Rabiotti Bros. confectioners, 50 Amiens street Great empire, and how fancy is "fried fish saloon"?

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The surnames of the other members of the Rabaiotti houshold in the 1901 census [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] referenced are Santi, Marenghi, Sodoli, Franzoni, Borlenghi, Garvie and Santi. All ice cream dealers labourers and all born in Italy. Mrs Rabaiotti was born in America, but the 5-year-old daughter was born in Dublin, so they were very probably there in 1896.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the Weekly Irish Times of Saturday, 31 May 1902:
THE SUPPOSED POISONING CASE IN DUBLIN The City Coroner, Dr Byrne, resumed on Tuesday the inquest which had been adjourned from the 19th on the body of Joseph Quinn, aged 13 years, who resided in Grant's row, and who died in hospital on the 17th from poisoning. Mr. A.E. Ennis appeared for Mr. Rabaiotti, ice cream vendor at Gigas Bazaar, at whose stall deceased, it was stated, purchased some wafers on the 15th inst. Dr. Joynt, on the previous occasion, stated in his evidence that the boy presented symptoms of acute poisoning, and the case was adjourned pending an analysis of the stomach of deceased, and some ice-cream similar to that which he was supposed to have eaten. Mr. Rabaiotti, who carries on his business in Amiens street, was examined, and deposed to the ingredients of his ice-cream, against the quality of which there had never been a complaint. His business at the bazaar was stopped about three o'clock on the 15th, when he gave a sample of the ice-cream to the police, who came back about 6.30 p.m. and said he might resume. Dr. McWeeney deposed to being unable to find any traces of poison in the ice-cream and wafers submitted to him for analysis. He ate one of the wafers and suffered no ill effects. The Coroner read for the jury a report from Sir Charles Cameron of his analysis of the viscera of deceased. So far as poison was concerned the result was negative. There was nothing in the appearance of the stomach or intestines to suggest corrosive poisoning. The liver was abnormal. The jury found that death was due to exhaustion, and exonerated Mr. Rabaiotti from all blame in connection with the matter.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: If this is c.1910 (which seems likely), then am intrigued to note that the railings for the chalet bunker de nécessité are visible behind Moore's statue. It might sound a weird thing to ponder, but I used to work close-by, and wondered how long those were in situ before the Council closed them. Am still intrigued that the various underground conveniences remain closed, and the Council haven't yet reopened for original intent, replaced with something similar, or re-purposed for something "out of the box" (mini-museum, tourist info, café, whatever). Appreciate that in the 70s and 80s these places were no-go areas (drug taking, dealing, "amourous" liaisons, etc), but I wonder if we've moved on...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The other ice cream car belongs to Peter and Serofina Chervi of Capel Street, sadly unmentioned in Ulysses, unless in this somewhat uncomplimentary aside: On the contrary that stab in the back touch was quite in keeping with those italianos though candidly he was none the less free to admit those icecreamers and friers in the fish way not to mention the chip potato variety and so forth over in little Italy there near the Coombe were sober thrifty hardworking fellows except perhaps a bit too given to pothunting the harmless necessary animal of the feline persuasion of others at night so as to have a good old succulent tuckin with garlic de rigueur off him or her next day on the quiet and, he added, on the cheap.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Oh well done, Niall! I'd been looking for Chervy as it's spelt on the ice cream car and couldn't come up with anything. Wonder was it a sign writer's error, or an anglicisation of Chervi?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
From the Dublin City [Court] Sessions report in the Weekly Irish Times on Saturday, 8 October 1904:
... COUNTERFEIT COIN Two young men named Wm. Byrne and Henry Murray pleaded guilty to uttering a counterfeit 5s. piece to Peter Chervi. Mr. Bushe, K.C., said that this was one of those coinage cases of which there were quite a number. In this particular case they came with a 5s. to Mr. Chervi which was bad. They were already in the publichouse of a man named Rutledge, where they were told it was bad. The prisoners were put back. Subsequently they were allowed out on their own recognizances, the detectives stating that they believed the young men got the coin from another person. The men bore a good character...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] People today have forgotten the meaning of the phrase "Wait until the penny drops". It was cast into the brass slot machine on many public toilets. The big old penny had to rattle through the mechanism before you turned the doorknob, otherwise the thing jammed. The old currency was replaced in 1971. I cannot find a photo anywhere on the web of these old coin mechanisms. Public toilets are disappearing rapidly. You need a strong bladder in Blackpool. www.maturetimes.co.uk/health/health-news/1359-%E2%80%9Cpu...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] The sculptor was Christopher Moore (1790 - 1863) (any relation??). The Dictionary of Irish Artists (1913) was very critical of this statue -
" ... [Christopher] Moore's work largely consisted of portrait busts, in which he was very successful. They are well modelled and expressive likenesses; but his powers were unequal to larger or more important works, and in his statues and figure subjects he was not successful; his grotesque effigy of Thomas Moore, in College Street, is an unfortunate memorial to the poet. "
From - www.libraryireland.com/irishartists/christopher-moore.php [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] That page says Christopher Moore also did a bust of Jonathan Henn, QC in 1846 - small serendipitous world!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The DIA says of Moore: His full-size statue of Thomas Moore in College Street, Dublin, which was erected in 1857(2) attracted much hostile criticism.(3)

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: Great title from 'Ulysses'- opening of the Circe episode "wedged lumps of coral and copper snow" as printed in the 'corrected' text established by Hans Walter Gabler and now somewhat discredited. The latest edition annotated by Sam Slote reverts to the more usual "coal and copper snow". Great to see how it would have looked to Mr Bloom as he wandered across the city in 1904.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56225952@N06] How could "Coal" be an ice-cream flavour??? Do the usual editions mispell Mr. Rabaiotti's name as "Pabaiotti" a few pages later?

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] I agree 'coal' does sound odd however it makes sense if Joyce is describing the colour of the ice cream as seen in the flickering light illuminating the scene with the shadows the colour of coal. All of my editions spell 'Rabaiotti' correctly (e.g. Bodley Head edition 1962 p.566).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56225952@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] So, am I changing the title to Coal and Copper Snow? Have to say I kind of prefer Coral and Copper Snow, but willing to be guided by someone who has "editions"...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: How about just Copper Snow, so that we stay onside of both Gabler and Slote? :)
